g.text: The lithium lanthanum zirconium oxide garnet, Li
recent years due to its high room temperature lithium ion conductivity and its stability against lithium
metal. Together these features make it a promising electrolyte candidate for a high energy all solid-state
battery. Previous studies have shown that incorporation of aluminum cations during the synthesis
stabilizes the higher conductivity cubic phase of LLZ; however the incorporation process and its eÔ¨Äect
on the phase transition are still unclear. In the present study, we have combined powder X-ray
Li MAS NMR and high-resolution X-ray diÔ¨Äraction (HRXRD) to determine the
disposition of Al cations during the formation of low temperature cubic LLZ. At temperatures as low as
C, the aluminum is incorporated into amorphous or nanocrystalline grain boundary phases. Above
C, the Al cations are associated with a poorly crystalline anti-Ô¨Çuorite phase Li
anions. This phase then reacts with tetragonal LLZ to form cubic LLZ over a 25 hour
C. Although the reaction appears complete by powder X-ray diÔ¨Äraction,
spectra showed overlapping resonances suggesting multiple Al environments due to uneven
substitution of the 24d Li(1) site. This was conÔ¨Årmed by high-resolution XRD and was consistent with a
series of closely related cubic LLZ phases with slightly diÔ¨Äerent Al concentrations, indicating the slower
) diÔ¨Äusion within the lattice has not reached equilibrium in the time allotted. The disorder over the
two crystallographic tetrahedral sites by lithium and aluminum cations at this temperature contributes
to the observed lattice enlargement associated with the low temperature cubic phase.
Batteries based on lithium metal anodes have always been
intriguing for energy storage based systems because they oÔ¨Äer
signiÓÑÉcant potential beneÓÑÉts including increased cell voltage,
simpler electrode design, and high energy density. However, the
practical application of lithiummetal as a rechargeable anode is
problematic due to its reactivity with electrolytes and its poor
electrodeposition properties which can lead to high surface area
One approach to address the reactivity
issue is to use a stable solid electrolyte with high lithium-ion
conductivity to create a physical barrier between the metal
anode and the electrolyte components. This approach actively
de-solvates the lithium cations as well as acts as a barrier to
prevent solvent attack on the freshly deposited metal surface.
Although numerous solid ion conductors have been evalu-
ated, the lithium lanthanum zirconium oxide garnet,
(LLZ), has received signiÓÑÉcant attention due to its
high lithium ion conductivity and its stability against lithium
Two polytypes have been reported with the garnet
structure: a high temperature cubic phase with high ionic
has been reported that aluminum cations, incorporated during
the synthesis, stabilize the cubic phase
however the stabilizing eÔ¨Äect of Al is not
for Li according to the mechanism Al
reduction of the Li content and an increase in the Li vacancies,
which strongly aÔ¨Äects the phase stability and the conductivity.
It has also been reported that the presence of Al could enhance
the sintering process and lead to higher density pellets.
LLZ polytypes have been prepared by traditional solid-state
of the literature showed that for solid-state and high tempera-
ture solution-based syntheses at least one calcination step at
C or above as well as a minimumamount of Al (>0.5 wt%)
are necessary to form the cubic phase.
been synthesized starting from solution-based precursors at
